item.title: Rocket.Chat and the Matrix Protocol
item.description: Rocket.Chat federation support via the Matrix protocol. This announcement is an exciting one to me. I’ve been working with Rocket.Chat since I found it over almost 7 years ago. item.title: OVH Serial over LAN (SOL)
item.description: Its been a while since I’ve worked with physical servers and typically when something happened I could pretty quickly get physical access to the box if things went pear shaped. But when you buy or lease servers from a provider like OVH. Those servers might be sitting half way around the world. So if something goes wrong you need to some how virtually be in front of the keyboard. OVH has a few different ways to access your servers console to interact with the machine directly.

item.title: Tinkerbell or iPXE boot on OVH
item.description: Recently have had to work with a number of physical servers that need to be treated more cattle like than a bunch of pets. I need to be able to quickly and easily provision servers to fit a specific role with out having to go through a complicated setup process. For this type of thing PXE or iPXE comes to the rescue. Allowing you to boot over the network. Simply rebooting the machine and then having it pick up its instructions and be provisioned like needed.

item.title: Getting public ip from CLI
item.description: I’ve found my self on occasion needing to find the public IP of a machine while in commandline(CLI).Â Most of the time its just because i’ve spoiled my self with DNS entries, and haven’t memorized it. You need to have curl installed.Â If you don’t have it, it should be in your package manager.Â In Ubuntu its easily installed via: sudo apt-get install curl Then just simply run: curl ifconfig.me I figured since I hadn’t posted in a while, this is a useful enough tidbit to share.

item.title: IPv6 Connectivity in Ubuntu: Setting up
item.description: With ICANN recently announcing the end of IPv4 addresses to allocate, its time to take a look at the future. What is IPv6? According to CiscoÂ IPv6 is: IP Version 6. Replacement for IPv4. A next generation IP protocol. IPv6 is backward compatible with and is designed to fix the shortcomings of IPv4, such as data security and maximum number of user addresses. IPv6 increases the address space from 32 to 128 bits, providing for an unlimited number of networks and systems.
